column1: An insulinoma is a tumor in the pancreas that produces too much insulin.
The pancreas is an organ in the abdomen.
Insulin's job is to reduce the level of sugar (glucose) in the blood by helping it move into cells.
Tumors of the pancreas that produce too much insulin are called insulinomas.
Hypoglycemia may be mild, leading to symptoms such as anxiety and hunger.
These tumors are very rare in children.
90% of insulinomas are non-cancerous (benign) tumors.
People with specific genetic syndromes such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type I are at risk of insulinomas and other endocrine tumors.

After fasting, your blood may be tested for: - Blood C-peptide level - Blood glucose level - Blood insulin level - Drugs that cause the pancreas to release insulin Abdomen CT, MRI, or PET scan may be done to look for a tumor in the pancreas.
Surgery is the recommended treatment for insulinoma.
If there are many tumors, part of the pancreas will need to be removed (partial pancreatectomy).
15% of the pancreas must be left to produce its enzymes for digestion.
If no tumor is found during surgery, or if you are not a candidate for surgery, you may get the medicine diazoxide to lower insulin production and prevent hypoglycemia.
A diuretic (water pill) is given with this medicine to prevent the body from retaining fluid.
Another medicine, octreotide, is used to reduce insulin release in some people.
In most cases, the tumor is non-cancerous (benign), and surgery can cure the disease.
Call your health care provider if you develop any symptoms of insulinoma.
